title.narrative: F.a: Formalizing Informal Community Health Work in Sub-Sahara Africa

description.narrative: In many African countries, part of health care, especially in village communities - but also in cities - is taken care by volunteer workers. They receive only a brief introduction to the work, compensation for the work is inadequate and occupational safety is often not properly taken care of. However, many of them work full time. Most of these community health workers are women. The project will improve the rights and status of community health workers in South Africa, Zambia and Malawi. The aim is to forma lize their status as employees. This includes being secured by labour laws and the right to a minimum wage. The long-term goal of the project is that community health workers enjoy the same rights as other workers. In the first phase, the aim is to strengt hen the trade unions' understanding of the problems in the sector and their ability to reach and train the community health workers to know and demand their rights. The project will directly benefit community health workers in South Africa, Zambia and Mala wi, as well as their families. With improved health care, the project will indirectly benefit all residents in the countries. The project is implemented by Public Services International PSI, together with its affiliates in South Africa, Zambia and Malawi. The project is supported by the trade union JHL in Finland.
